docs.snippet: The deal could double the personal fortune of Mark Zuckerberg, Facebook's co-founder.Facebook, the popular social networking site, has raised $500 million from Goldman Sachs and a Russian investor in a deal that values the company at $50 billion, ...
docs.lead_paragraph: The deal could double the personal fortune of Mark Zuckerberg, Facebook's co-founder.Facebook, the popular social networking site, has raised $500 million from Goldman Sachs and a Russian investor in a deal that values the company at $50 billion, according to people involved in the transaction. The deal makes Facebook now worth more than companies like eBay, Yahoo and Time Warner. The stake by Goldman Sachs, considered one of Wall Street's savviest investors, signals the increasing might of Facebook, which has already been bearing down on giants like Google. The new money will give Facebook more firepower to steal away valuable employees, develop new products and possibly pursue acquisitions - all without being a publicly traded company. The investment may also allow earlier shareholders, including Facebook employees, to cash out at least some of their stakes.

headline.main: Facebook Deal Puts Its Value At $50 Billion

docs.abstract: Facebook has reportedly raised $500 million from Goldman Sachs and Russian investment firm Digital Sky Technologies in deal that values popular social networking site at $50 billion, more than several other online giants; stake by Goldman, considered among Wall Street's savviest investors, signals increasing might of Facebook, and will give it more firepower to steal away valuable employees, develop new products and possibly pursue acquisitions--all without being publicly traded company; new investment may also allow earlier shareholders, including Facebook employees, to cash out at least some of their stakes; deal comes as Securities and Exchange Commission has begun inquiry into increasingly hot private market for shares in Internet companies, inquiry that some experts suggest is focused on whether companies are improperly skirting public disclosure requirements; photo (M)

byline.original: By ANDREW ROSS SORKIN and EVELYN M. RUSLI

docs.snippet: How did Facebook end up worth more, theoretically, than one of the world's largest media conglomerates?...
docs.lead_paragraph: Word arrived Monday that Facebook, the burgeoning social media company that surpassed Google last year as the most visited Web site, was worth $50 billion based on a deal done by Goldman Sachs. By way of comparison, our colleagues Andrew Ross Sorkin and Evelyn M. Rusli pointed out that the company was worth more than Time Warner, the large United States media company, which closed the day with a market cap of about $37 billion.

headline.main: Facebook vs. Time Warner: A Not-So-Rigorous Financial Evaluation

docs.abstract: How did Facebook end up worth more, theoretically, than one of the world's largest media conglomerates?

docs.snippet: BAER--Fernand B. Jr. October 10, 1935-December 28, 2010. We have lost an irreplaceable friend. Our hearts are shattered. Our cherished Tony was a gentleman, scholar, and the most devoted friend anyone could have. He gave without hesitation in ways...
docs.lead_paragraph: BAER--Fernand B. Jr. October 10, 1935-December 28, 2010. We have lost an irreplaceable friend. Our hearts are shattered. Our cherished Tony was a gentleman, scholar, and the most devoted friend anyone could have. He gave without hesitation in ways that cannot be measured. No matter what, he was ever curious, vibrant, full of humor and eager to embrace life at its fullest. No matter what, he was compassionate, generous, and a lifesaver and buoy to any friend in need. No matter what, he never complained. Instead, he strode forth, with a smile on his face, ready to do good and bring joy. For Tony, every day was an opportunity to learn something new to add to his already impressive and vast store of knowledge. His was the gift of truly listening and selfless caring for others. A virtual one-man Google, one's inbox never stayed empty if he knew you needed to know whatever it was. How lucky were we to have him in our family. How painfully silent it is now that he is gone. We pray that he is at peace. He will forever be missed. All our Love, Catherine, Fred, Christopher and Freddie

headline.main: Paid Notice: Deaths  BAER, FERNAND B

docs.snippet: In this week's podcast, Andrew Ross Sorkin talks about Facebook and its investors, and Phil Simon, author of "The New Small," discusses small business and technology....

Bettina Edelstein speaks with Andrew Ross Sorkin, the editor of DealBook, about what the investment does for the social networking giant.

headline.main: TechTalk Podcast: Facebook's Investors

docs.abstract: In this week's podcast, Andrew Ross Sorkin talks about Facebook and its investors, and Phil Simon, author of "The New Small," discusses small business and technology.

docs.snippet: A leading Tunisian blogger and activist has gone from prison to cabinet minister in less than a week....
docs.lead_paragraph: Updated | 3:26 p.m. Less than two weeks ago, Slim Amamou, a Tunisian blogger and activist, was using his @slim404 Twitter feed to let friends know that the police had been to his house. Later the same day, after he was arrested, the 33-year-old computer programmer managed to turn his phone on and log on to Google Latitude to broadcast his location: inside the country's feared ministry of the interior.

headline.main: Tunisian Blogger Joins Government

docs.abstract: A leading Tunisian blogger and activist has gone from prison to cabinet minister in less than a week.

docs.snippet: As the Google Android platform closes in on the iPhone, will Apple decide to offer its successful phone on multiple carriers?...
docs.lead_paragraph: Nick Bilton/The New York TimesAmong the several impressive numbers that Apple shared in its latest quarterly earnings report on Tuesday was the sale of more than 16 million iPhones over the quarter. Next month sales will surely continue to rise as Apple starts selling the iPhone on the Verizon network. But if Apple wants to fend off the iPhone's rivals, will it have to sell its signature mobile device on other networks as well? Some analysts say yes.

headline.main: Will Apple Put the iPhone on Other Carriers?

docs.abstract: As the Google Android platform closes in on the iPhone, will Apple decide to offer its successful phone on multiple carriers?

headline.seo: Google Co-Founder Takes Over as Chief Executive
headline.main: Google Shake-Up Is Effort to Revive Start-Up Spark

byline.original: By CLAIRE CAIN MILLER and MIGUEL HELFT

docs.snippet: SAN FRANCISCO -- Google made the biggest management shake-up in a decade on Thursday, handing the reins of the company to one of its co-founders in an effort to rediscover its start-up roots.     As it has grown into the dominant company in Silico...
docs.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO -- Google made the biggest management shake-up in a decade on Thursday, handing the reins of the company to one of its co-founders in an effort to rediscover its start-up roots. As it has grown into the dominant company in Silicon Valley, Google has lost some of its entrepreneurial culture and become a slower-moving bureaucracy, analysts and insiders say, in contrast to Facebook, Twitter and other younger, more agile competitors.

headline.main: CO-FOUNDER BACK AT GOOGLE'S HELM

docs.abstract: Google makes biggest management shake-up in decade, handing reins of company to co-founder Larry Page in effort to rediscover its start-up roots; analysts and insiders say that as Google has grown into dominant company in Silicon Valley it has lost some of its entrepreneurial culture and become slower-moving than some other younger, more agile Web juggernauts, like Facebook and Twitter; to counter this, Google announces that Page will take over as chief executive from Eric E Schmidt, technology industry veteran who was brought in decade ago to provide more mature leadership; sudden rise of Facebook has exposed Google's failures in areas like social networking and threatens its vast share of online advertising market; photo (M)

byline.original: By CLAIRE CAIN MILLER and MIGUEL HELFT; Claire Cain Miller contributed reporting

docs.snippet: Larry Page’s move to chief executive will test his skills at handling the daily grind of running a business....

headline.main: A Creator Prepares to Take the Reins at Google

docs.snippet: Because of an editing error, an article on Friday about a management shake-up at Google misstated the details of the company's control. The co-founders, Sergey Brin and Larry Page, and the chief executive, Eric E. Schmidt, together control the com...
docs.lead_paragraph: Because of an editing error, an article on Friday about a management shake-up at Google misstated the details of the company's control. The co-founders, Sergey Brin and Larry Page, and the chief executive, Eric E. Schmidt, together control the company through their shares; they do not each have ''controlling stakes.'' (While the three hold slightly more than 20 percent of the outstanding shares, a dual stock structure gives each of the founders about 28 percent of the voting power and Mr. Schmidt about 9 percent.)

headline.main: Corrections

docs.snippet: Apple sold more than 16 million iPhones in the last quarter, according to its earnings report. Next month sales will surely continue to rise as Apple starts selling the iPhone on the Verizon network. But if Apple wants to fend off the iPhone's riv...
docs.lead_paragraph: Apple sold more than 16 million iPhones in the last quarter, according to its earnings report. Next month sales will surely continue to rise as Apple starts selling the iPhone on the Verizon network. But if Apple wants to fend off the iPhone's rivals, will it have to sell its signature mobile device on other networks as well? Some analysts say yes. The iPhone's fiercest competitor is Google's Android platform, in phones that are available on all the major United States carriers.

headline.main: Weighing Value Of iPhone Cachet

docs.abstract: Bits blog; Apple may have to offer iPhone on other carriers besides AT&T and Verizon if it wants to keep its dominant position over competitors (M)

docs.snippet: In the brave new world of media -- or the brave world of new media -- turnabout is most definitely fair play. Google, for instance, advertises itself in newspapers and trade publications. And now a leading paper company is promoting one of its pro...
docs.lead_paragraph: In the brave new world of media -- or the brave world of new media -- turnabout is most definitely fair play. Google, for instance, advertises itself in newspapers and trade publications. And now a leading paper company is promoting one of its products with a series of online video clips. The company is Sappi, and the product is Flo, Sappi's value-priced, or economy, line of paper. To gain a following for Flo among a target audience of printers and press operators, Sappi is sponsoring humorous webisodes under the title ''Off Register.''

headline.main: Paper Company Wants Printers to Go the 'Flo' Way

docs.snippet: BUSINESS DAY     An article on Friday about Google's quarterly earnings gave an incorrect percentage for the increase in revenue for the fourth quarter from the fourth quarter a year earlier. Revenue climbed to $8.44 billion from $6.67 billion, fo...
docs.lead_paragraph: BUSINESS DAY An article on Friday about Google's quarterly earnings gave an incorrect percentage for the increase in revenue for the fourth quarter from the fourth quarter a year earlier. Revenue climbed to $8.44 billion from $6.67 billion, for an increase of 26 percent, not 17 percent.

headline.main: Corrections

docs.snippet: An article on Saturday about Larry Page's pending takeover as Google's chief executive misstated the year that he made a commencement speech at the University of Michigan, his alma mater. It was 2009, not ''last year.'' (The commencement speaker i...
docs.lead_paragraph: An article on Saturday about Larry Page's pending takeover as Google's chief executive misstated the year that he made a commencement speech at the University of Michigan, his alma mater. It was 2009, not ''last year.'' (The commencement speaker in 2010 was President Obama.) (Go to Article)

docs.snippet: This week's e-mail bag brought a note that echoes the sentiments of many others:      ''Hi David! Am I the only one getting really confused by all the free/cheap Internet calling options? Would you mind  clearing the steadily occluding waters of S...
docs.lead_paragraph: This week's e-mail bag brought a note that echoes the sentiments of many others: ''Hi David! Am I the only one getting really confused by all the free/cheap Internet calling options? Would you mind clearing the steadily occluding waters of Skype, Google Voice, Line2, FreePhone2Phone, and so on? Your fan, Caroline C.''

headline.main: Ins and Outs Of Calling Via the Net

docs.abstract: David Pogue State of The Art column on variety of free and inexpensive calling applications available for Android phones and iPhones, as well as many Web-based computer options; says that as Internet connections improve, developers are increasingly creating better software for online phone connections, rapidly changing nature of making calls; photos; drawing (M)

docs.snippet: David Pogue gets a lesson on word usage....
docs.lead_paragraph: In my Times column Thursday, I quoted a reader who asked: "Would you mind clearing the steadily occluding waters of Skype, Google Voice, Line2, and so on?"

headline.main: A Conclusion on Occlusion

docs.abstract: David Pogue gets a lesson on word usage.

docs.snippet: The State of the Art column on Thursday, about Internet calling apps, described the capabilities of such apps incorrectly. A few of them allow free calls to regular phone numbers from cellphones; it is not the case that no apps meet that descripti...
docs.lead_paragraph: The State of the Art column on Thursday, about Internet calling apps, described the capabilities of such apps incorrectly. A few of them allow free calls to regular phone numbers from cellphones; it is not the case that no apps meet that description. The column also misstated the capabilities of Google Voice. Besides offering free domestic calls from your computer, the service also allows free calls from a landline phone and, with the use of an app called Talkatone, from a cellphone. It is not the case that it does not allow free calls from a phone.

headline.main: Corrections
